title: Publish library to Maven Central with Gradle and GitHub Actions
description: Creating a library using Gradle, register at Maven Central and publish it to Maven Central using GitHub Actions
author: Simon Scholz

children.value: When you want to publish a library to Maven Central you have to follow a few steps. This tutorial will guide you through the process of creating a library using Gradle, register at Maven Central and publish it to Maven Central using GitHub Actions.
Gradle installed on your local machine. You can download it from
A GitHub repository where you'll host your library.
A Sonatype OSS account (required for publishing to Maven Central).
A GPG key for signing your artifacts.
If you already have a library you can skip this step.
Create a new Gradle library project using the following command:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: Besides kotlin-library you can also use various other types, which you can find here:
In order to publish to maven central you need to publish your library in public, e.g., on

or others.
I'd recommend using GitHub for this, since we'll also use GitHub Actions to publish the library to Maven Central.
When creating the repository on GitHub, make sure to add a
To publish your library to Maven Central you can use the
plugin. This plugin will take care of all the necessary steps to publish your library to Maven Central.

Maven Central requires that all non
artifacts are signed. Therefore we need to sign all publications.
It is also required to add certain meta data, which can either be specified within the

props.className: language-properties shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
GROUP=io.github.simonscholz
POM_ARTIFACT_ID=qr-code-with-logo
VERSION_NAME=0.4.0-SNAPSHOT

POM_NAME=QR Code with logo
POM_DESCRIPTION=Customizable qr code generatation with different colors and shapes and logos using awt
POM_INCEPTION_YEAR=2023
POM_URL=https://github.com/simonscholz/qr-code-with-logo/

POM_LICENSE_NAME=The Apache Software License, Version 2.0
POM_LICENSE_URL=https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0.txt
POM_LICENSE_DIST=repo

POM_SCM_URL=https://github.com/SimonScholz/qr-code-with-logo
POM_SCM_CONNECTION=scm:git:git://github.com/simonscholz/qr-code-with-logo.git
POM_SCM_DEV_CONNECTION=scm:git:ssh://git@github.com/simonscholz/qr-code-with-logo.git

POM_DEVELOPER_ID=simonscholz
POM_DEVELOPER_NAME=Simon Scholz
POM_DEVELOPER_URL=https://github.com/simonscholz/

The credentials you use here will be used later on to sign in at

children.value: Publish a SNAPSHOT of your library to Maven Central

Now you can already publish SNAPSHOTs of your library to Maven Central.
In order to do so the version of the library needs to end with
Just add the credentials into your

props.className: language-properties shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: file located in the project folder, since this file will be committed to your repository and therefore the credentials will be public.
Then in your project folder you can run:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: you can also use environment variables:

children.value: This approach will also be used later on in the GitHub Actions workflow.
Using the snapshot from maven central
In order to use the snapshot from maven central you need to add the following to your

props.className: language-kotlin shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value:
is the URL of the snapshot repository.
Also see
Publishing the SNAPSHOT using a GitHub Action

In order to build and publish the SNAPSHOT using a GitHub Action you can use the following workflow.
This workflow will be triggered on every push and pull request, but the publish step will only be executed when the push is on the

props.className: language-yaml shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
name: CI

on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  jvm:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: gradle/wrapper-validation-action@v1

      - uses: actions/setup-java@v3
        with:
          distribution: 'temurin'
          java-version: 21

      - uses: gradle/gradle-build-action@v2.9.0

      - name: Build
        run: ./gradlew build

  publish:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    if: github.repository == 'SimonScholz/qr-code-with-logo' && github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
    needs:
      - jvm
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: actions/setup-java@v3
        with:
          distribution: 'temurin'
          java-version: 21

      - uses: gradle/gradle-build-action@v2.9.0

      - name: Publish Artifacts
        run: ./gradlew publishAllPublicationsToMavenCentral
        env:
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_mavenCentralUsername: ${{ secrets.SONATYPE_USERNAME }}
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_mavenCentralPassword: ${{ secrets.SONATYPE_PASSWORD }}

children.value: Note that you need to add the

as secrets to your repository.
In order to do that you need to go to your repository on GitHub, then click on

children.value: We'll now walk through the whole process creating a GPG key, but you can also have a look at the
You'll not have many users of your library if you only provide snapshots. Therefore you'll need to publish releases of your library to Maven Central, which requires you to sign your artifacts.
First of all GnuPG needs to be installed:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
gpg --version

# Should produce a similar output:
gpg (GnuPG) 2.2.27
libgcrypt 1.9.4
Copyright (C) 2021 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
License GNU GPL-3.0-or-later <https://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html>
This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it.
There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.

Home: /home/simon/.gnupg
Supported algorithms:
Pubkey: RSA, ELG, DSA, ECDH, ECDSA, EDDSA
Cipher: IDEA, 3DES, CAST5, BLOWFISH, AES, AES192, AES256, TWOFISH,
        CAMELLIA128, CAMELLIA192, CAMELLIA256
Hash: SHA1, RIPEMD160, SHA256, SHA384, SHA512, SHA224
Compression: Uncompressed, ZIP, ZLIB, BZIP2

children.value: You'll be prompted to enter your real name, your email address and a passphrase, when generating a key:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: The output will look similar to this:
Make sure to keep your passphrase and private key protected!

Other people and maven central itself need your public key to verify your signed files.
Therefore you have to distribute your public key to a key server:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: You can then search your key on
and see that it is available there.
Please have a look at the
folder and check if there is a

file.
In case there already is a
file you can skip this step.
file, then you need to export your private key:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: This secring.gpg file can now be used in the following steps.

props.className: language-properties shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: # must be the short key id format
# must be the absolute path to the secring.gpg file, ~/.gnupg/secring.gpg won't work
Adjust the values for username, password, keyId, passphrase and the path to the secring.gpg file accordingly.
To get the short key id use the following command:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: With this setup you can now run
to publish your signed library to Maven Central.
For the GitHub Actions workflow we need to export the private key and use it in the workflow by utilizing action secrets, since there won't and shouldn't be a

in place you can export your private key and show it in the terminal.
This can later be used in a GitHub Actions workflow:

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
gpg --export-secret-keys --armor ${key-id} ${path-to-secring.gpg} | grep -v '\-\-' | grep -v '^=.' | tr -d '\n'

# e.g.

gpg --export-secret-keys --armor 93118BDD624014E8EF9A83847D0C56D86BBFCAA3 ~/.gnupg/secring.gpg | grep -v '\-\-' | grep -v '^=.' | tr -d '\n'

children.value: When running this command you'll be prompted to enter your passphrase, which you specified earlier during the key generation.
Warning: Make sure to keep your private key protected! With the command above you'll print your private key to the terminal.
Adjust the GitHub Action to publish gpg signed artifacts
Now that we have the private key we can adjust the GitHub Action workflow to use it.

props.className: language-yaml shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
name: CI

on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  jvm:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: gradle/wrapper-validation-action@v1

      - uses: actions/setup-java@v3
        with:
          distribution: 'temurin'
          java-version: 21

      - uses: gradle/gradle-build-action@v2.9.0

      - name: Build
        run: ./gradlew build

  publish:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    if: github.repository == 'SimonScholz/qr-code-with-logo' && github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
    needs:
      - jvm
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: actions/setup-java@v3
        with:
          distribution: 'temurin'
          java-version: 21

      - uses: gradle/gradle-build-action@v2.9.0

      - name: Publish Artifacts
        run: ./gradlew publishAllPublicationsToMavenCentral
        env:
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_mavenCentralUsername: ${{ secrets.SONATYPE_USERNAME }}
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_mavenCentralPassword: ${{ secrets.SONATYPE_PASSWORD }}
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_signingInMemoryKey: ${{ secrets.SIGNING_IN_MEMORY_KEY }}
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_signingInMemoryKeyId: ${{ secrets.SIGNING_KEY_ID }}
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_signingInMemoryKeyPassword: ${{ secrets.SIGNING_PASSWORD }}

children.value:
must be added as secret environment variables.
Remember that the
must be the short key id format.
So far we only published SNAPSHOTs of our library to Maven Central, but since we now also have accoplished the signing of our artifacts we can also publish real releases.
First of all we need to adjust the version of our library by removing the

props.className: language-properties shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: from the version, you can now run
to prepare a release for Maven Central.
Once this is done you can either run
Or to do everything in one shot the formerly created
block can be extended like this:

props.className: language-kotlin shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: Using a GitHub Action to publish releases
In order to publish releases using a GitHub Action you can use the following workflow.

props.className: language-yaml shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
name: Release

on:
  release:
    types: [ published ]

jobs:
  publish-release:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    if: github.repository == 'SimonScholz/qr-code-with-logo'
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: actions/setup-java@v3
        with:
          distribution: 'temurin'
          java-version: 21

      - uses: gradle/gradle-build-action@v2.9.0

      - name: Publish Artifacts
        run: ./gradlew publishAllPublicationsToMavenCentral --no-configuration-cache
        env:
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_mavenCentralUsername: ${{ secrets.SONATYPE_USERNAME }}
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_mavenCentralPassword: ${{ secrets.SONATYPE_PASSWORD }}
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_signingInMemoryKey: ${{ secrets.SIGNING_IN_MEMORY_KEY }}
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_signingInMemoryKeyId: ${{ secrets.SIGNING_KEY_ID }}
          ORG_GRADLE_PROJECT_signingInMemoryKeyPassword: ${{ secrets.SIGNING_PASSWORD }}

children.value: For a completely headless release the complete publising should be enabled by passing
function as described in the previous section.

props.className: language-kotlin shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value:
file must be pushed to the main branch and a release must be created on GitHub.
This will trigger the
workflow, which will then publish the release to Maven Central.
